title: Bridging the Gap: How to Support a Child or Partner with Alexithymia in Hyderabad
excerpt: Does your child struggle to describe how they feel, only to have a meltdown minutes later? This often isn't stubbornness ‚Äî it could be Alexithymia. Learn what it is and how families in Hyderabad can build bridges to emotional understanding.
author: Tauseef Mohammed
content:
A parent in Hyderabad describes her nine-year-old son: "He never tells me he is sad. He never tells me he is worried. And then, completely out of nowhere ‚Äî he explodes. Or shuts down entirely. I can't understand it." A wife comes to us concerned because her husband "never seems to care" when she is upset, and yet she can see that he clearly loves her deeply. What both of these families may be encountering is a little-understood but relatively common trait called Alexithymia ‚Äî and at Maryam Child Development Studio in Hyderabad, we work with families navigating it every day.

What is Alexithymia?

Alexithymia is derived from the Greek: a (without), lexis (words), thymos (emotion). Literally, it means "without words for emotion." It is a personality trait ‚Äî not a diagnosis ‚Äî characterised by difficulty identifying, describing, and processing one's own emotional states. Research suggests that approximately 50% of autistic individuals in Hyderabad and globally experience significant alexithymia, compared to approximately 10% of the general population.

Importantly, alexithymia is not the same as lacking emotions. People with alexithymia often feel emotions very intensely. The challenge is that these emotions do not automatically "translate" into conscious awareness or verbal description. Instead of registering "I am feeling anxious," the person may only register physical sensations: a tight chest, a heavy stomach, a racing heart, or a sudden, unexplained urge to leave the room.

Why Alexithymia Matters for Hyderabad Families

In Hyderabad's family and school cultures, emotional expression and responsiveness are deeply valued. When a child cannot articulately say "I am upset" or "I am scared," they are often misread as indifferent, rude, or manipulative. Teachers in Hyderabad may interpret a child's blank expression during a distressing situation as defiance or lack of empathy. Parents may feel that their emotionally unexpressive child doesn't care about the family, when in fact the child may be profoundly affected but entirely unable to translate that affect into word or expression.

Understanding alexithymia changes this picture entirely ‚Äî and it is a change that our clinical team at Maryam CDC Hyderabad helps families make every day.

Practical Strategy 1: The Somatic Detective Approach

For children and adults with alexithymia, asking "How do you feel?" is often an unanswerable question. The emotional landscape that this question assumes is simply not accessible. But shifting to "Where do you feel it in your body?" opens a completely different door. We teach Hyderabad families to help their children become "Somatic Detectives" ‚Äî investigators of physical sensation. "Is your tummy tight? Is your chest heavy? Does your face feel hot?" These body-based questions bypass the emotional labelling system and access something more fundamental: physical awareness.

Over time, with patient practice, many children begin to connect the physical sensations they can identify with the emotional states they previously had no language for. "My tummy being tight" becomes associated with "I am worried."

Practical Strategy 2: Visual Tools for Emotional Literacy

Abstract emotion vocabulary is difficult for many children with autism and alexithymia in Hyderabad. Visual tools make emotions concrete and visible:

  • Emotion Wheels: Circular charts showing a range of emotions in a visual format help children identify and point to how they feel without requiring verbal description. We create personalised versions for children at Maryam CDC Hyderabad using familiar contexts and culturally relevant imagery.
  • Emotional Thermometers: A visual scale from "calm" to "extremely upset" that the child can point to, helping them communicate the intensity of feeling even when they cannot name it.
  • Comic Strip Conversations: Drawing simple social situations in comic strip format and filling in speech and thought bubbles helps children with alexithymia visualise the internal emotional states of both themselves and others in a concrete, manageable way.

Practical Strategy 3: Co-Regulation and Being an External Brain

For a child with alexithymia and autism in Hyderabad, the parent or caregiver often needs to serve as the child's "External Brain" for emotional regulation. This means providing the emotional labelling, the regulation strategies, and the co-regulation that the child's internal systems cannot yet provide for themselves. Sitting calmly next to the child during a meltdown, speaking slowly and gently naming what might be happening ("I think your body might be really tired right now ‚Äî that's okay"), and offering regulated presence without demands allows the child's nervous system to gradually borrow the calm from the adult's regulated state.

Practical Strategy 4: Explicit Communication ‚Äî Dropping the Hints

Hyderabad's relational culture, like many South Asian cultures, often relies heavily on implicit communication ‚Äî hints, tone, facial expression, and context. For a person with alexithymia, this implicit layer is largely invisible. Hinting that you are upset, hoping your partner or child will notice your tone and respond, is a strategy that will consistently fail with alexithymia. The solution is radical explicitness: "I am feeling hurt right now because X happened. I need Y from you." Direct, clear, non-blaming communication is not a sign of a broken relationship ‚Äî it is the relationship adaptation that allows genuine connection to occur.

Rethinking Love Languages for Hyderabad Families

The popular concept of "Love Languages" assumes that people express and receive love in five primary ways: words of affirmation, acts of service, receiving gifts, quality time, and physical touch. For individuals with alexithymia, the picture is more nuanced. Solving a problem for someone, researching a solution to their distress, or providing practical help may be a person's deepest available form of empathy ‚Äî not a sign that they don't care, but a sign that they care so much they immediately shifted into problem-solving mode. Recognising this re-frames what might feel like emotional coldness as a different, equally valid expression of love and connection.

Getting Support at Maryam Child Development Studio Hyderabad

Alexithymia doesn't have to mean disconnection. With the right strategies, the right support, and a shared vocabulary, families in Hyderabad can build profound and meaningful relationships with their neurodivergent loved ones.
